alert.note: Alert for Weber (Utah) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 15 at 11:59AM MDT until further notice by NWS Saltlake
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Utah... South Fork of The Ogden River Near Huntsville affecting Weber County. Sevier River Near Hatch affecting Garfield, Piute, Kane, Sevier and Iron Counties. .Recent warm temperatures and upstream dam releases will continue to result in increased river flows. Minor flooding is ongoing along the South Fork of the Ogden River near Huntsville. For the Sevier River...including Hatch...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and near moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...South Fork of The Ogden River Near Huntsville. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 4.6 feet (992 CFS), low lying areas near the banks of the South Fork of the Ogden River below Causey Reservoir through the town of Huntsville will receive minor flooding. At 5.5 feet (1599 CFS), low lying areas adjacent to the South Fork of the Ogden River below Causey Reservoir through the town of Huntsville will receive moderate flood damage. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:15 AM MDT Monday the stage was 4.7 feet (1051 CFS). - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:15 AM MDT Monday was 5.4 feet (1487 CFS). - Forecast...The river will oscillate above minor flood stage through Monday before rising to near 5.4 feet (1550 CFS) Tuesday, May 16, per the latest forecast. By Wednesday, May 17, the river is forecast to rise to 5.5 feet (1580 CFS). - Flood stage is 4.6 feet (992 cfs). &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by Tuesday at 1200 MDT.
